conclusion: Analyze the given velocity-time (v-t) graph to determine if the speed difference is continuously increasing.
The graph shows two curves representing the velocities of objects A and B over time.
Define velocity functions: v_A(t) for object A and v_B(t) for object B.
The difference in speed is given by |v_A(t) - v_B(t)|.
At t = 0, both objects start from the same point on the velocity axis, v_A(0) = v_B(0).
The velocity of object A increases and then decreases, forming a parabolic shape.
The velocity of object B also increases and then decreases, reaching its peak later than object A.
Initially, both objects have the same velocity. As time increases, object A's velocity increases faster than object B's, causing the difference |v_A(t) - v_B(t)| to increase.
After reaching their peaks, both velocities start to decrease, but object A's velocity decreases faster than object B's.
The difference in speed increases as long as the velocities diverge and decreases when they converge.
The difference in speed between the two objects is not continuously increasing.
Final answer: The difference in speed is not continuously increasing during the time interval from 0 to t_1.
